questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation. The mother has had no prenatal care. His 6-year-old sister has a history of osteosarcoma. He is exclusively breastfed. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactosemia is a rare metabolic disorder that often manifests with cataracts. While this patient presents with possible findings of cataract (e.g., leukocoria and strabismus), he has no other features of galactosemia (e.g., hepatomegaly, jaundice). Moreover, galactosemia would normally be detected by newborn screening or become apparent in the first few days after birth and initiation of breast milk rather than manifest at 4 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Visual training therapy is indicated in many patients with strabismus. Treatment of strabismus should be initiated as early as possible to prevent amblyopia and loss of binocular vision. However, although this patient has strabismus, visual training therapy is not indicated because the presence of leukocoria is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, which requires further investigation.

C) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the eye is an important step in the evaluation of the size and extent of retinoblastoma prior to surgery. Although this patient's presentation is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, other interventions are preferred over CT scan, which increases the risk of radiation-induced tumors in patients with RB1 gene mutation. CT scan is occasionally considered if retinoblastoma is clinically suspected but difficult to confirm.

D) INCORRECT:

Occlusion therapy (i.e., an eye patch) is often indicated in patients with strabismus to prevent amblyopia and loss of binocular vision. However, although this patient has strabismus, occlusion therapy is not indicated at this point because the presence of leukocoria is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, which requires further investigation.

E) CORRECT:

All children who present with leukocoria should undergo a prompt funduscopic examination to rule out retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common and, if left untreated, most lethal primary intraocular malignancy in children. The condition typically manifests with leukocoria, strabismus, and a white mass in the retina on fundoscopy. Less commonly, there is visual impairment and/or redness of the eye due to inflammation. Ocular ultrasound and MRI are indicated to evaluate the size and extent of the tumor. Treatment is primarily surgical, with specific surgical techniques (e.g., cryotherapy vs. enucleation) dictated by imaging results. Chemotherapy is used as an adjuvant if there is metastatic disease.

Retinoblastoma is caused by sporadic or inherited mutations in the retinoblastoma gene (Rb) and may be associated with other malignancies (e.g., osteosarcoma, pinealoma). This patient's sister has a history of osteosarcoma, which suggests an inherited mutation. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.
Image Description:

Photograph of a patient with retinoblastoma

The left eye shows the normal retinal reflection, whereas the right pupil appears white (leukocoria or white pupil). This phenomenon occurs if light (e.g., during an ophthalmologic examination or flash photography) is not reflected by the retina but by intraocular lesions such as tumors.

Leukocoria is a typical early symptom of retinoblastoma.

F) INCORRECT:

Observation with follow-up is indicated for isolated strabismus in children < 3 months old, as it often resolves spontaneously. However, this patient's leukocoria with concurrent strabismus raises suspicion for retinoblastoma, the most common and, if left untreated, fatal primary intraocular malignancy in children. All children who present with leukocoria should undergo further examination.

G) INCORRECT:

Serum rubella titers should be acquired in cases of suspected rubella. This patient's mother has not had routine prenatal care, which puts her at risk of contracting congenital infections, including rubella. Rubella infection during pregnancy may cause congenital rubella syndrome, typically manifesting with sensorineural hearing loss, cataracts, and/or cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus) at birth or later. Although cataracts may cause leukocoria and strabismus, other features of congenital rubella syndrome are absent in this patient (e.g., cardiopulmonary abnormalities). Another investigation is warranted in this patient to rule out retinoblastoma.
questions.hint: All children who present with leukocoria should be considered to have retinoblastoma until proven otherwise.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He has no history of serious illness. His older sister had an eye disease that required removal of one eye at the age of 3 years. Examination shows inward deviation of the right eye. Penlight examination shows a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. The patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is the most common malignancy in infants. About half of all cases are associated with amplification and overexpression of oncogene MYCN caused by deletions of the short arm of chromosome 1. A higher incidence of neuroblastoma has been described in patients with Hirschsprung disease, neurofibromatosis type 1, and Turner syndrome. However, there is no association with hereditary retinoblastoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common hematologic malignancy in children. As a secondary malignancy in patients with hereditary retinoblastoma, however, it is extremely rare. Genetic diseases that increase the risk for development of ALL include Down syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, and ataxia-telangiectasia.

C) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common cutaneous malignancy and associated with sun exposure. While hereditary retinoblastoma is associated with a higher risk of malignant melanoma, it is not associated with an increased risk for basal cell carcinoma.

D) CORRECT:

Patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations (Rb gene mutations) have a significantly increased risk of developing osteosarcomas. Usually, a germline mutation takes place in one of the alleles of the Rb gene only and development of retinoblastoma does not occur until a spontaneous mutation of the second, priorly functioning allele results in a nonfunctioning Rb gene (two-hit hypothesis). Sporadic retinoblastomas, on the other hand, are caused by two spontaneous mutations in the same retinal cell, affecting both Rb alleles.

All children who present with leukocoria should be considered to have retinoblastoma until proven otherwise and should undergo prompt fundus examination. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.
Image Description:

In most cases, retinoblastoma is caused by a loss of function mutation in both alleles of RB1 (tumor suppressor gene).

Hereditary retinoblastoma (top): Due to a germline mutation (more often de novo than inherited), one altered allele is present in all cells. Retinoblastoma develops if a mutation occurs in the second allele (“second hit”).

Sporadic retinoblastoma (bottom): Initially, both alleles are normal. A mutation must occur in both alleles in the same cell for retinoblastoma to develop.

E) INCORRECT:

Most gastric cancers are sporadic; only a minority of cases are associated with hereditary factors (e.g., hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer). There is no increased risk for patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations. Moreover, gastric cancer is extremely rare in children.

F) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma is the most common renal malignancy in children. Only a minority of cases are associated with loss of function mutations (esp. WT1 gene on chromosome 11) and specific syndromes (e.g., WAGR syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome). There is no increased risk for patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations.
questions.hint: This patient has a unilateral white light reflex (leukocoria), which can be a sign of retinoblastoma. The family history of an eye condition that required enucleation strongly suggests a germline mutation in the retinoblastoma gene.

questions.text:
A 7-month-old boy is brought in by his parents who are concerned because “his left eye turns inward.” He was born at 34 weeks’ gestation after preterm prelabor rupture of membranes and required a weeklong stay in the neonatal intensive care unit, where he received antibiotics and oxygen therapy. He currently lives at home with both his parents and a new puppy. He was previously reaching age-appropriate developmental milestones but, during the past month, has had increasing difficulty with tracking. His mother has a history of hypertension, and his father had a history of a bone tumor as an adolescent.
On physical examination, the patient is normocephalic with normal eye size; however, he has notable left-sided esotropia. An attempt to elicit a red reflex reveals the following findings (figure).
The patient is referred to pediatric ophthalmology for immediate examination under anesthesia and is found to have bilateral intraocular masses.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Persistent fetal vasculature of the eye

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Persistent fetal vasculature is a nonhereditary, congenital malformation related to a failure of the embryonic vascular connective tissue of the eye to regress. It frequently manifests with leukocoria, but it is almost always unilateral and is often associated with microphthalmia.

B) INCORRECT:

Coats disease (primary retinal telangiectasia) is a rare, exudative retinopathy and is unilateral in approximately 90% of cases. It commonly affects boys aged 5 to 10 years but can appear earlier and is nonhereditary.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital cataracts are opacifications of the lens of the eye that are typically diagnosed at birth and not typically associated with esotropia.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s initial eye examination revealed strabismus and bilateral leukocoria. Given his father’s history of a bone tumor, his eye findings most likely represent bilateral retinoblastoma with a mutation in the RB1 gene. The presence of intraocular masses on further evaluation further supports the diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is the most common cancer of the eye in children and accounts for approximately 3% of all childhood cancers. Ninety percent of retinoblastomas occur before age 5, and most occur before age 2. Retinoblastoma can occur as part of a cancer predisposition syndrome involving mutation of the RB1 gene. Individuals with mutations in RB1 are at increased risk for other tumors, including osteosarcoma, and can pass on this gene in an autosomal dominant fashion.

The most common presenting sign of retinoblastoma is leukocoria, followed by strabismus. Any child with leukocoria must be referred to ophthalmology immediately for an examination under anesthesia, and early referral to oncology should be considered.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an infant who has leukocoria, strabismus, and bilateral intraocular masses is retinoblastoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxocariasis (visceral larva migrans) is caused by Toxocara canis, a helminth parasite that is found in dogs and can be transmitted to humans. This parasite can grow in the back of the eye, causing leukocoria and mimicking retinoblastoma. However, ocular toxocariasis typically occurs unilaterally, and this patient has bilateral eye findings.

questions.text:
An 8-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. His mother reports noticing a whitish reflection in his right eye in photographs, while the left eye appears normal. His medical and birth histories are unremarkable, and he demonstrates normal growth and development. On examination, the right eye lacks a red reflex, and visual fixation is less robust in the right eye.
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infantile glaucoma presents with tearing, photophobia, and buphthalmos due to elevated intraocular pressure, causing diffuse corneal haziness. The unilateral absent red reflex and lack of systemic signs of increased intraocular pressure make this diagnosis unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Endophthalmitis usually follows ocular trauma, surgery, or systemic infection and presents with pain, redness, and vitreous haze. The absence of these symptoms and a history of ocular intervention or injury makes this diagnosis unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, often presenting before age 2. Leukocoria, or a whitish reflection in the pupil, occurs when light reflects off the tumor instead of the normal choroid, leading to an absent red reflex. Impaired visual fixation suggests retinal disruption by the tumor. Imaging, such as ocular ultrasound or computed tomography, may reveal intraocular calcifications, characteristic of retinoblastoma. Mutations in the RB1 gene contribute to its pathogenesis, emphasizing the need for early detection.

Key learning point: An absent red reflex in an infant is a red flag for retinoblastoma, the most common intraocular tumor in children, and requires urgent evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Uveal melanoma arises from melanocytes in the uveal tract and typically affects middle-aged or elderly individuals. The age and presentation of an 8-month-old with leukocoria and decreased visual fixation do not align with this condition, which is rare in infants.

questions.text: You are seeing a 1-year-old boy for a well-child examination. He has no history of serious illness. His older sister had an eye disease that required removal of one eye at age 3. On examination, there is inward deviation of his right eye. Penlight examination reveals a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. This patient is at increased risk for which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations (Rb gene mutations) have a significantly increased risk of developing osteosarcomas. Usually, a germline mutation takes place in one of the alleles of the Rb gene only and development of retinoblastoma does not occur until a spontaneous mutation of the second, priorly functioning allele results in a nonfunctioning Rb gene (two-hit hypothesis). Sporadic retinoblastomas, on the other hand, are caused by two spontaneous mutations in the same retinal cell, affecting both Rb alleles.

All children who present with leukocoria should be considered to have retinoblastoma until proven otherwise and should undergo prompt fundus examination. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.

Key learning point: Hereditary retinoblastoma due to Rb gene mutations increases the risk of developing osteosarcoma as a secondary malignancy.
Image Description:

In most cases, retinoblastoma is caused by a loss of function mutation in both alleles of RB1 (tumor suppressor gene).

Hereditary retinoblastoma (top): Due to a germline mutation (more often de novo than inherited), one altered allele is present in all cells. Retinoblastoma develops if a mutation occurs in the second allele (“second hit”).

Sporadic retinoblastoma (bottom): Initially, both alleles are normal. A mutation must occur in both alleles in the same cell for retinoblastoma to develop.

B) INCORRECT:

Basal cell carcinoma is the most common cutaneous malignancy and associated with sun exposure. While hereditary retinoblastoma is associated with a higher risk of malignant melanoma, it is not associated with an increased risk for basal cell carcinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Neuroblastoma is the most common malignancy in infants. About half of all cases are associated with amplification and overexpression of oncogene MYCN caused by deletions of the short arm of chromosome 1. A higher incidence of neuroblastoma has been described in patients with Hirschsprung disease, neurofibromatosis type 1, and Turner syndrome. However, there is no association with hereditary retinoblastoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Nephroblastoma is the most common renal malignancy in children. Only a minority of cases are associated with loss of function mutations (esp. WT1 gene on chromosome 11) and specific syndromes (e.g., WAGR syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome). There is no increased risk for patients with inherited retinoblastoma gene mutations.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common hematologic malignancy in children. As a secondary malignancy in patients with hereditary retinoblastoma, however, it is extremely rare. Genetic diseases that increase the risk for development of ALL include Down syndrome, neurofibromatosis type 1, and ataxia-telangiectasia.
questions.hint: This patient has a unilateral white light reflex (leukocoria), which can be a sign of retinoblastoma. The family history of an eye condition that required enucleation strongly suggests a germline mutation in the retinoblastoma gene.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-month-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation, and his mother did not receive prenatal care. His 6-year-old sister has a history of osteosarcoma. He is exclusively breastfed. On examination, you note inward deviation of his right eye. Penlight examination reveals a white reflex in the right eye and a red reflex in the left eye. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Galactosemia is a rare metabolic disorder that often manifests with cataracts. While this patient presents with possible findings of cataract (e.g., leukocoria and strabismus), he has no other features of galactosemia (e.g., hepatomegaly, jaundice). Moreover, galactosemia would normally be detected by newborn screening or become apparent in the first few days after birth and initiation of breast milk rather than manifest at 4 months of age.

All children who present with leukocoria should undergo a prompt funduscopic examination to rule out retinoblastoma. Chemotherapy is used as an adjuvant if there is metastatic disease.

Retinoblastoma is caused by sporadic or inherited mutations in the retinoblastoma gene (Rb) and may be associated with other malignancies (e.g., osteosarcoma, pinealoma). This patient's sister has a history of osteosarcoma, which suggests an inherited mutation. Molecular genetic testing is recommended in all patients with retinoblastoma to identify germline mutations, as family members may also be at risk.

Key learning point: Leukocoria in infants is a classic sign of retinoblastoma and warrants immediate funduscopic examination to confirm the diagnosis and initiate prompt management.
Image Description:

Photograph of a patient with retinoblastoma

The left eye shows the normal retinal reflection, whereas the right pupil appears white (leukocoria or white pupil). This phenomenon occurs if light (e.g., during an ophthalmologic examination or flash photography) is not reflected by the retina but by intraocular lesions such as tumors.

Leukocoria is a typical early symptom of retinoblastoma.

Although cataracts may cause leukocoria and strabismus, other features of congenital rubella syndrome are absent in this patient (e.g., cardiopulmonary abnormalities). Another investigation is warranted in this patient to rule out retinoblastoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the eye is an important step in the evaluation of the size and extent of retinoblastoma prior to surgery. Although this patient's presentation is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, other interventions are preferred over CT scan, which increases the risk of radiation-induced tumors in patients with RB1 gene mutation. CT scan is occasionally considered if retinoblastoma is clinically suspected but difficult to confirm.

E) INCORRECT:

Occlusion therapy (i.e., an eye patch) is often indicated in patients with strabismus to prevent amblyopia and loss of binocular vision. However, although this patient has strabismus, occlusion therapy is not indicated at this point because the presence of leukocoria is highly concerning for retinoblastoma, which requires further investigation.
